awd_titl_txt: CRISP Type 1: Data-driven Real-time Simulation for Adaptive Control of Interdependent Infrastructure Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The functioning of interdependent critical infrastructures such as water, electricity, gas, transportation and telecommunications is highly reliant on sensors, data networks, and control services that are enabled by computer hardware and software systems, which in turn cannot function without electric power and sufficient cooling capacity. The interdependency and interconnected nature of these cyber-physical systems has increased the possibility that a minor disturbance in one infrastructure can cascade into a regional outage across several infrastructure systems. The human response to such outages, both on the supply and demand sides, is crucial and mainly influenced by the perception of emerging risk and the ability to take rational decisions. This project is developing a framework for modeling collaborative adaptive capabilities that are driven by human cognitive abilities and preferences in order to minimize the risk of cascading failures across infrastructure systems. The cyber-physical-psychological interplay investigated in this project will have widespread benefits to infrastructure managers, emergency response teams and policy makers enabling them to more effectively deal with emerging crises. This project also offers inter-disciplinary research opportunities for undergraduates and underrepresented students in addition to graduate student mentoring.

The research objective is to advance real-time predictive capabilities of cascading failures across interdependent critical infrastructures by aligning the simulation model architecture with human adaptive preferences to enable rational decision making in the face of emerging unprecedented risks. Three interconnected tasks will be undertaken to achieve this objective: (1) the cognitive abilities and adaptation preferences of infrastructure control room operators (and organizations they represent) will be modeled using cognitive task analysis techniques; (2) an integrated real-time simulation model for electricity-gas-water networks will be developed  through time-synchronization of individual dynamic simulation models using a system-in-the-loop framework; and (3) the capabilities of computational intelligence techniques such as  cellular computational networks in predicting near-future system states will be evaluated. Particular attention will be paid to the ability of infrastructure operators to visualize an emerging threat through the developed model architecture and embedding their adaptive preferences in the predictive modeling framework to rationalize response decision making. This project will advance understanding of both spatial and temporal extents of cascading failures through continuous learning of the simulation model using real-time monitoring data from SCADA systems. With advancements on several fronts, the research outcomes will contribute to realizing autonomous adaptive control of critical interdependent infrastructures.

por.por_cntn:
This CRISP project investigated the dynamic interactions of Interdependent Critical Infrastructures (ICIs) and mapped the interdependencies at power-water-gas (PWG) exchange points by studying infrastructural data from a real-world coastal urban area. The project also designed a near-real-time ICI simulation model to account for temporal and spatial failure cascades. Moreover, it also examined the human part of the human-cyber-physical systems (“humans in the loop”) that make up these ICIs.

The findings from this project can be classified into two numerical and psychological categories based on their intellectual merits:

(1)   The coastal urban area PWG networks underwent robust metaheuristic optimization procedures to apply the optimal operational solution for the ICI model. The results of the ICI model in the baseline and sensitivity analysis scenarios reveal that the model is reliable and robust under various boundary conditions amid different-sized cascading failure scenarios. Different minimum pressure criteria and failure initiation points were examined to evaluate the model behavior and assess the temporal and spatial propagation of the cascading failures. Besides, the robust ICI platform in this study is intrinsically developed such that it can be universally applied to other power and water layouts. The numerical analysis that the proposed model provides paves the way for accurate simulations of various complex failures to design or retrofit an efficient backup system. Also, variations of minimum pressure criteria at generators play a more significant role than other studied variables in optimizing the temporal behavior of the system of systems for response planning. Furthermore, numerical delineation of temporal and spatial failure cascades across the ICIs in this study provides real-time knowledge to control and engineer the travel time and propagation pattern in an optimal way.

 

(2)   The utilities are tied together in multi-level, interactive, interdependent human as well as physical/cyber interdependent networks. The extent of the human network goes well beyond the utility organizations themselves. Predictions of physical interactions and dependencies among the utility systems by simulation models will obviously have operational effects such as operator-level interactions. But those interactions are well-defined and have been honed by years of direct interactions and operations of the physical systems. Model predictions will also affect multiple parts of the extensive human ICI network(s). We found that non-operational interaction links are not simple or straightforward – there is a multi-nodal network of interaction paths (relationships) among the people in the systems that include non-utility organizations ranging from the obvious (relevant government agencies) to much less obvious (outage management software conferences). These interactions can affect the operations of the physical-cyber interdependent network in ways that go beyond the obvious operational decisions at both the operator and management levels (e.g., operators maintaining homemade databases of physical vs. listed addresses for pump stations - critical for reporting station outages).  These interactions also have substantive implications for pre-emergency planning and coordination. Resilience in ICIs could be enhanced by systematic characterization and use of this “extended” human network.

The broader impacts of this research project include: (a) offering prospects for adopting the proposed ICI model at power or water utilities for failure prediction and associated response planning in real-time where distributed natural gas-based power generation is utilized; (b) contributing to swifter crisis management strategies to mitigate large-scale risks associated with extreme failure scenarios such as hurricanes; (c) providing a robust, quantitative interdependent infrastructural model for the research community to improve upon; (d) raising awareness for stakeholders regarding the existing human cognitive biases at PWG utilities for decision-making amid small- or large-scale failure events; (e) producing knowledge and insight about the synchronization of inter-network crisis maneuvers among PWG utilities for optimal entertainment of first response; (f) publication of numerous research articles and research presentations to disseminate the specific findings of this research project; and (g) research training of multiple undergraduate and graduate students in the important area of management of interdependent critical infrastructures during failure events.
